item.title: Gravitational wave mission passes 'sanity check' - BBC News
item.description:
Gravitational wave mission passes 'sanity check' - BBC News

From the section Science & Environment A European Space Agency effort to try to detect gravitational waves in space is not only technically feasible but compelling, a new report finds. A panel of experts was asked to perform a "sanity check" on the endeavour, which is likely to cost well in excess of one billion euros.

item.title: Moore's Law Is About To Be Reborn
item.description:
Moore's Law Is About To Be Reborn

2021. This is the year that the 2015 International Technology Roadmap for Semiconductors, released earlier this month, predicts that it will no longer be economically viable for companies to continue shrinking the size of transistors, the fundamental units of computer processors that have historically dictated the maximum component density that can be squished onto a wafer of silicon.

item.title: Watch 2,600 Years Of Culture Grow And Die | The Creators Project
item.description:
Watch 2,600 Years Of Culture Grow And Die | The Creators Project

We've seen gorgeous data visualizations of geotagged tweets to get a look into which countries are hot for Twitter, and even a real-time map of emoji usage around the globe, but one researcher is plotting a broader aspect of human life: the birthplace of culture and where it goes to die.

item.title: DARPA: We Are Engineering the Organisms That Will Terraform Mars
item.description:
DARPA: We Are Engineering the Organisms That Will Terraform Mars

Terraformed Mars, artist's conception. Image: Daein Ballard/Wikimedia Commons It's no secret that the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency is investing heavily in genetic engineering and synthetic biology.

item.title: The Metaphysical Astronauts
item.description:
The Metaphysical Astronauts

When Edgar Mitchell died last week, the flurry of obituaries that followed each noted his impressive career as an astronaut; specifically, that he was the sixth person to walk on the Moon.

item.title: Asimo meets Pepper: Honda and Softbank partnering in robots
item.description:
Asimo meets Pepper: Honda and Softbank partnering in robots

Automaker Honda Motor Co. and internet company SoftBank said Thursday they will work together on artificial intelligence to develop products with sensors and cameras that can converse with drivers. Tokyo-based Honda's robotics division went through some soul-searching when Asimo was widely criticized as useless when it could not help with the nuclear accident at the Fukushima plant, which sank into meltdowns after the March 2011 tsunami.

item.title: NASA Just Released a Bunch of Sweet Vintage Space Posters | The Creators Project
item.description:
NASA Just Released a Bunch of Sweet Vintage Space Posters | The Creators Project

Images via NASA Just like every other kid interested in the cosmos, my childhood bedroom ceiling was covered in luminous stars and planets. If the light had just turned, they'd burn on; I spent my nights dreaming about what it would be like to travel to other worlds.

item.title: IBM's Watson Will Morph Polite Pepper Into an Ultra-Intelligent Evil Genius
item.description:
IBM's Watson Will Morph Polite Pepper Into an Ultra-Intelligent Evil Genius

Pepper is super cute and remarkably well-mannered... for now. But that IBM just announced that the talking, emotion-reading robot will interface with Watson, lil Pep could turn into a smiling, evil robotic mastermind; adorable leader of the human-enslaving resistance.

item.title: Inside the Artificial Intelligence Revolution: Pt. 1
item.description:
Inside the Artificial Intelligence Revolution: Pt. 1

Welcome to robot nursery school," Pieter Abbeel says as he opens the door to the Robot Learning Lab on the seventh floor of a sleek new building on the northern edge of the UC-Berkeley campus. The lab is chaotic: bikes leaning against the wall, a dozen or so grad students in disorganized cubicles, whiteboards covered with indecipherable equations.

item.title: People can sense single photons
item.description:
People can sense single photons

Juliet White/Getty Images People can detect flashes of light as feeble as a single photon, an experiment has demonstrated - a finding that seems to conclude a 70-year quest to test the limits of human vision. The study, published in Nature Communications on 19 July, "finally answers a long-standing question about whether humans can see single photons - they can!"
